cheapListings.description: You will find easy living features in all of our studios, one, and two-bedroom apartments including carpeting, wood style flooring, and more. Community features include a sparkling pool, barbecue pits on site, and lush landscaping. Very centrally located minutes from the best entertainment and shopping centers in San Antonio. Make life easy in San Antonio with your new home at 410 Heights!
cheapListings.long_highlight: Discover the perfect fusion of comfort and convenience at 410 Heights, centrally situated in San Antonio. With a location offering a 34% cost-effective advantage over the metro average, residents benefit from immediate proximity to numerous recreational, dining, and retail options. The property features well-appointed studios, one, and two-bedroom apartments complete with modern comforts such as air conditioning and hardwood floors. The community amenities include a sparkling pool and inviting barbecue grill areas, surrounded by lush landscaping, creating a welcoming environment for relaxation. Highly praised by residents as 'Great people! Great place to live!', it's an ideal sanctuary for those seeking vibrant city life without compromising on comfort.
cheapListings.short_highlight: 410 Heights showcases a vibrant living experience with its superb amenities and central location in San Antonio. Enjoy easy access to schools, parks, and restaurants all within walkable distances. The delightful community pool and on-site BBQ areas offer residents a charming outdoor atmosphere.
cheapListings.highlight_title: Ideal blend of convenience and lifestyle in San Antonio.

cheapListings.description: Introducing Diamond Ridge, nestled in the heart of San Antonio, TX, where vibrant urban living meets serene garden-style tranquility. Our community boasts a lush landscape of manicured lawns, blooming flower beds, and shady tree-lined pathways, offering residents a retreat from the hustle and bustle of city life. Whether you're strolling through our picturesque grounds or unwinding in one of our spacious apartment homes, you'll experience a perfect blend of nature and modern convenience at Diamond Ridge.
cheapListings.long_highlight: Diamond Ridge offers a harmonious blend of nature and modern living in San Antonio. Enjoy strolls through lush, manicured landscapes with blooming flower beds and shady pathways that provide a haven of peace. This property is priced below the metro average, offering a cost-effective option for those seeking comfort and convenience. With air conditioning, in-unit laundry, a gym, and a pool among the many amenities, residents can indulge in a lifestyle marked by luxury and ease. Located within a mile of schools, parks, and various dining establishments, Diamond Ridge is perfect for those who value both relaxation and accessibility.

cheapListings.description: Find your new home here at Station at Elm Creek. Enjoy newly renovated spacious studio, one, and two bedroom apartment homes. Contact our professional management team for more information and to start your application for Station at Elm Creek today!

Indulge in on-site amenities like a luxurious pool, BBQ area, and state-of-the-art fitness center, perfect for active lifestyles. Nestled in the vibrant heart of San Antonio, it offers the perfect balance of city living with convenient access to fantastic local dining, shopping, and entertainment options. With transportation easily accessible, commuting and exploring the city becomes a breeze. Ideal for those seeking a stylish and convenient urban lifestyle, Station at Elm Creek is your gateway to enjoying all that San Antonio has to offer.

Stay active at our 24-hour fitness center, spend time outdoors at our picnic area, or dip in the refreshing swimming pool. We know you'll also love our children's playground, basketball court, tennis court, volleyball court, dog park, business center, and on-site laundry facility.

Residents relish the convenience of a fully equipped gym open around the clock, an inviting pool, and various sports courts, including basketball, tennis, and volleyball. This pet-friendly complex even offers a dedicated dog park and playground, making it ideal for families and pet lovers alike. With 31 restaurants and several parks within walking distance, residents have access to fabulous dining and outdoor adventures just seconds away. Embrace the dynamic living experience offered by The Iris, where generous storage, private patios, and an excellent location make it a wonderful place to call home.

topRatedListings.description: Welcome to Berkshire at the Rim Apartments in Northwest San Antonio, one of the town’s trendiest havens for the urban dweller. Sit down, meet the neighbors over a cup of your favorite beverage, then take the party outdoors to the grilling spots or the resort-style swimming pool with cabanas. If you have a gym membership, you can ditch it with confidence as we have a state-of-the-art, 24-hour fitness center and a private spin-room with a yoga zone. Plus, our San Antonio apartments near the Methodist Healthcare System and BASIS San Antonio Medical Center come with assigned carports, private garages, and 24/7 maintenance that add another layer of convenience.
topRatedListings.long_highlight: Berkshire at the Rim is a modern sanctuary offering luxurious amenities for those seeking a vibrant lifestyle in San Antonio. Located near the University of Texas at San Antonio, these apartments provide an ideal living experience with their in-unit laundry, state-of-the-art gym, and spacious patios. The community's standout features include a resort-style swimming pool with cabanas, a private spin-room, and chic resident spaces for socializing and relaxation. The ample parking options with private garages further enhance convenience. With an impressive array of dining and entertainment within walking distance, Berkshire at the Rim is a perfect choice for anyone wanting stylish living with superb accessibility.
topRatedListings.short_highlight: Berkshire at the Rim offers a chic urban dwelling located near the University of Texas at San Antonio. Residents can enjoy a vibrant lifestyle with plenty of restaurants and entertainment options just a walk away.

Blending style, quality, and modern amenities, Cottages at Leon Creek offers the perfect place to call home, where you can live the way you've always dreamed—without compromise.

The pet-friendly environment and amenities like a basketball court and business center ensure a well-rounded lifestyle for all residents.

cityLandingPageData.description: San Antonio blends rich history with modern amenities as one of Texas’ most culturally vibrant cities. Renters can enjoy trendy apartments near the River Walk with its restaurants, shops, and nightlife or opt for quieter neighborhoods like Alamo Heights for family-friendly living. Families often settle in areas like Stone Oak or Helotes for their spacious homes and excellent schools. With a thriving economy driven by industries such as healthcare, military, and tourism, San Antonio offers opportunity alongside its iconic attractions like the Alamo.

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Historic elegance defines Jefferson, where San Antonio's distinctive neighborhood showcases architectural diversity from Victorian to Craftsman just minutes north of downtown. The district sits walking distance to the popular Pearl District with its weekend farmers market and culinary destinations. Though rental rates exceed San Antonio averages, the combination of architectural distinction, established landscaping, and central positioning creates compelling value compared to newer construction lacking similar character.
knownFor: Established neighborhood with historic homes and community parks

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Historic character defines Collins Gardens, where modest homes west of downtown San Antonio offer architectural details at surprisingly accessible price points. The district sits within easy reach of both downtown employment and the developing Deco District with its emerging restaurant scene. Though some blocks show varied investment levels, the proximity to urban amenities without corresponding rental premiums creates significant value for those appreciating authentic San Antonio character beyond tourist districts.
knownFor: Affordable rentals with historic charm and easy downtown access

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Downtown accessibility defines Jefferson Heights, where San Antonio's near-downtown neighborhood offers historic character minutes from River Walk attractions. The district surrounds several small parks including Lockwood Park with its recreation facilities, while the developing commercial corridor along South St. Mary's Street provides both practical necessities and dining options within walking distance. Though some blocks show varied investment levels, the neighborhood's ongoing renaissance has created genuine community among both newcomers and longtime residents working together on improvement initiatives. The area's excellent public transportation includes multiple bus routes connecting to broader San Antonio destinations, while the relatively flat topography makes bicycle transportation practical throughout most months despite summer heat requiring early morning or evening rides during peak months.
knownFor: Historic district with growing arts and restaurant scene

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Historic character defines Terrell Heights, where mid-century bungalows and ranch homes create distinctive environment minutes from downtown San Antonio. The district sits adjacent to the popular Brackenridge Park with its golf course and Japanese Tea Garden, while the commercial areas along Broadway provide both practical necessities and dining options within easy reach. Though rental rates exceed San Antonio averages, the combination of architectural distinction, established landscaping, and central positioning creates compelling value compared to newer construction lacking similar character. The neighborhood's excellent school reputation attracts households willing to pay premium rates for educational access, creating stable rental demand despite housing market fluctuations.
knownFor: Family-friendly neighborhood with walkability and local shops

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: First-time renters appreciate Crown Meadows' combination of affordability and practical amenities in northwestern San Antonio. The neighborhood surrounds several parks including Crown Meadows Park with its playground facilities, while the nearby commercial district provides everyday necessities within easy reach. Though some properties show their age with dated interior finishes, the established tree canopy provides natural beauty and cooling shade during Texas summers – advantages impossible to replicate in newer developments with recently planted landscaping. The area's excellent school reputation attracts families seeking reasonable housing costs without educational compromises, creating stable rental demand despite more fashionable districts commanding higher prices elsewhere in the city.
knownFor: Residential area with newer developments and parks

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: First-time renters find excellent value in Dellview, where mid-century apartment buildings offer surprisingly spacious floor plans compared to newer construction. The neighborhood sits perfectly positioned between downtown employment and medical centers, creating reasonable commutes in multiple directions. Most properties include swimming pools that actually receive proper maintenance – a significant consideration during San Antonio's extended summer months.
knownFor: Residential area with a suburban feel
commonCons: Higher crime rates in certain parts

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Military families appreciate Bridgewood's combination of affordability and excellent school access near Fort Sam Houston. The neighborhood's garden-style apartments typically include family-friendly features like playground facilities, covered parking, and in-unit laundry connections essential for households with children. Unlike downtown options, most rentals include generous storage space – particularly valuable for service members managing deployment equipment between assignments.
knownFor: Residential neighborhood with a quiet atmosphere
commonCons: Higher crime rates in certain parts

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Medical professionals flock to Stone Oak for its luxury apartments within minutes of the growing hospital district. The neighborhood's hilltop location provides cooler temperatures and better breezes than downtown, with many units featuring Hill Country views from private balconies. Though rental rates exceed city averages, the trade-off includes resort-style amenities like infinity pools and outdoor kitchens actually worth using during San Antonio's extended summer.
knownFor: And proximity to major shopping centers

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Young families appreciate South Southwest's reasonable rents and proximity to Lackland AFB. The neighborhood features small apartment communities with actual green space and playgrounds that aren't afterthoughts squeezed between buildings. Unlike downtown options, most units include washer/dryer connections and generous storage – practical features that significantly impact daily living with children.
commonCons: Higher crime rates in certain parts

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Springvale offers affordable garden apartments with surprisingly spacious floor plans compared to trendier San Antonio neighborhoods. Most rentals include covered parking – essential during scorching Texas summers when vehicle interiors become unbearable without shade. The neighborhood's location provides quick access to both military installations and medical centers, making it popular with healthcare workers and service members seeking reasonable commutes.
knownFor: Residential neighborhood with a suburban feel
commonCons: Parts of the neighborhood are less developed
Higher crime rates in some areas

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Brewery District excitement continues transforming Lone Star, where former industrial buildings now house distinctive apartments with soaring ceilings and oversized windows flooding spaces with natural light. The neighborhood's renaissance centers around its namesake brewery complex, now featuring restaurants, arts spaces and creative businesses creating vibrant street life beyond residential functions. Living here means walking to both weekend entertainment and increasing employment opportunities as businesses continue relocating to this emerging district. Unlike suburban developments requiring vehicle ownership, the nearby Lone Star Hike and Bike Trail connects to downtown without traffic stress, while multiple bus routes provide broader city access without parking considerations. What creative professionals appreciate most: the area's industrial heritage remains evident through preserved architectural elements like loading docks and freight elevators now repurposed as distinctive building features celebrating manufacturing history rather than erasing it through generic redevelopment approaches.
knownFor: And easy access to local parks and shopping
commonCons: Can feel isolated from the city
Higher crime rates in certain areas

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Hemisfair Park workers and downtown professionals appreciate Lavaca's perfect positioning – close enough for walking commutes without the premium pricing of downtown proper. San Antonio's oldest residential neighborhood offers distinctive architectural character through its historic homes now sensitively divided into affordable apartments maintaining original details while updating systems for modern comfort. Unlike tourist-dominated downtown blocks, you'll find streets where residents outnumber visitors creating genuine community rather than theme-park atmospheres. The neighborhood's southern edge along Alamo Street provides urban conveniences from coffee shops to pharmacies without requiring vehicle trips, while multiple bus lines connect to broader San Antonio opportunities beyond walking distances. What elevates Lavaca beyond comparable neighborhoods: the community's active neighborhood association has maintained cohesive identity despite development pressures, fostering integration between longtime residents and newcomers through regular events creating connections beyond property boundaries.
knownFor: And a strong sense of community

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Military employees discover ideal housing in Government Hill, where historic homes near Fort Sam Houston offer the perfect compromise between base proximity and separation from work environments. The neighborhood's renaissance continues through thoughtful renovation preserving architectural details while updating systems for modern comfort. Pearl District's dining and entertainment sits walking distance from most rentals, eliminating designated driver concerns when enjoying San Antonio's emerging culinary scene. Unlike suburban military housing, these properties feature distinctive character with hardwood floors, higher ceilings, and architectural details reflecting San Antonio's rich building traditions. What service members appreciate most: the area's significant military population creates understanding of deployment schedules and relocation challenges, fostering community support systems particularly valuable during separation periods while maintaining separation from institutional base environments allowing genuine decompression after intense duty requirements.
commonCons: Some parts of the neighborhood are still underdeveloped

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Outdoor enthusiasts appreciate Friedrich Wilderness Park's unmatched access to nature within San Antonio city limits. Rental homes backing to the wilderness area offer direct trail access from your backyard – a genuine luxury for hikers and mountain bikers seeking weekday outdoor time without complicated planning. The neighborhood's slightly elevated position provides cooler temperatures than downtown San Antonio, particularly noticeable during summer months when even slight differentials significantly impact outdoor comfort. Unlike downtown options, most properties include covered parking – essential protection during Texas sun exposure that dramatically affects vehicle interior temperatures. The area's dark sky positioning away from central city light pollution creates exceptional stargazing opportunities from many rental properties, while bird watching opportunities abound along wilderness edges where residential areas interface with natural environments.
commonCons: Can feel isolated from urban amenities

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Family-focused renters appreciate Woodlawn Lake for its combination of affordability and exceptional park access, where duplexes and small apartment buildings surround the 30-acre lake and recreation complex. The neighborhood's rental options typically feature larger room dimensions than newer construction, with many units offering separate dining areas increasingly rare in contemporary floor plans. Weekend activities center around the park's playgrounds, fishing piers, and walking trails—creating free entertainment options particularly valuable for budget-conscious households. Though some properties show their age, the established tree canopy provides essential shade during San Antonio's long summer season—a natural amenity impossible to replicate in newer developments with recently planted landscaping.

Military renters appreciate Parkwood's proximity to Joint Base San Antonio along with its mix of affordable garden apartments and duplexes offering more space than on-base options. The neighborhood's location provides quick access to both downtown San Antonio attractions and major shopping centers, creating convenience without central city rental premiums. Flexible lease terms accommodate deployment schedules, with many landlords understanding military housing allowance timelines. Units typically feature practical amenities like covered parking and outdoor storage—particularly valuable for service members with equipment needs beyond standard apartment storage.

Historic character defines Los Angeles Heights-Keystone, where Spanish-influenced architecture creates distinctive rental options in this evolving San Antonio neighborhood. Apartments in converted homes feature architectural details uncommon in newer construction, from decorative tilework to arched doorways reflecting the area's cultural heritage. Though some streets show variable property maintenance, the area's strong community organizations actively work on neighborhood improvement initiatives. Renters enjoy proximity to both downtown San Antonio and the medical center employment cluster, creating flexible commuting options as work situations change.

Southwestern comfort characterizes Arbor At Sonoma Ranch, where architectural details inspired by Spanish and Mediterranean influences create distinctive neighborhood character in northern San Antonio. Residents enjoy community recreation facilities and the area's proximity to both shopping centers and natural areas like Canyon Springs Park. Though distance from downtown requires consideration for urban entertainment access, the trade-off comes in more square footage, modern energy efficiency, and thoughtfully designed outdoor living spaces. The neighborhood's location provides hill country views from many properties while maintaining reasonable commuting distance to major employers.

Natural beauty defines Spring Creek, where homes positioned along greenbelts and natural drainage areas create a park-like atmosphere despite suburban location. Residents enjoy walking trails connecting green spaces and wildlife viewing opportunities unusual for city-adjacent communities. Though flash flood considerations affect some low-lying areas during extreme rain events, most development follows thoughtful water management practices balancing environmental protection with practical housing needs. The neighborhood's varied topography creates interesting lot configurations with unexpected views and natural features that distinguish properties from cookie-cutter developments built on artificially flattened terrain.

Mid-century character defines Willshire Terrace, where ranch homes with distinctive architectural details create a cohesive neighborhood near Fort Sam Houston. Residents enjoy the quiet streets with mature trees and the area's central location with quick access to both downtown and major military facilities. Though some homes show their age with vintage systems requiring occasional maintenance, the trade-off comes in architectural character and established landscaping unavailable in newer developments. The neighborhood's proximity to military installations attracts service members seeking off-base housing with character, while the architectural significance appeals to those valuing distinctive design over cookie-cutter modernity.

Lakeside recreation defines Woodlake, where homes surrounding the neighborhood's namesake water feature enjoy parkland access and fishing opportunities unusual for urban settings. Residents appreciate the extensive Salado Creek Greenway trail system connecting to the broader San Antonio park network and the area's affordability compared to similar natural settings. Though distance from downtown requires commuting consideration, many households find the trade-off worthwhile for direct access to outdoor activities and larger properties than available in central districts. The community's diverse housing stock ranges from apartments to single-family homes, creating multi-generational living possibilities within the same neighborhood.

Family-focused living characterizes Northhampton, where established homes near the Medical Center attract healthcare professionals seeking reasonable commutes. Residents enjoy the neighborhood's mature trees providing essential shade during hot summers and the community's quiet residential character despite proximity to major employers. Though building aesthetics favor practical functionality over distinctive architecture, the stable community and central location create reliable investment value beyond flashier alternatives. The area's proximity to major medical facilities attracts both long-term employees and visiting medical professionals, creating a community that understands the unique schedules and demands of healthcare careers.

Established elegance characterizes Oak Park-Northwood, where mid-century homes with distinctive architectural details create one of San Antonio's most desirable neighborhoods inside Loop 410. Residents enjoy the sprawling McAllister Park with its extensive trail system and the neighborhood's convenient location between downtown and airport. Though some older homes require modernization of original systems, the trade-off comes in architectural character, larger lots, and established landscaping unavailable in newer developments. Many homes feature surprising details from terrazzo floors to built-in planters that showcase the optimism and creativity of post-war American design applied to San Antonio's distinctive climate and lifestyle.

Academic influence shapes College Park, where affordable homes near San Antonio College attract both students and young professionals seeking urban convenience. Residents enjoy walking access to campus facilities including the community theater and library alongside the evolving restaurant scene along San Pedro Avenue. Though some properties show deferred maintenance reflecting rental conversion patterns, the neighborhood's bungalows and Victorian cottages provide character rarely found at similar price points. The area's central location provides quick access to both downtown employment and the Pearl District's entertainment options, creating practical living solutions for those balancing work and educational opportunities.

Historic character defines Beacon Hill, where bungalows and Victorian homes create one of San Antonio's most architecturally significant neighborhoods north of downtown. Residents enjoy walking to the area's coffee shops and restaurants along Fredericksburg Road and the proximity to the Pearl District's weekend farmers market. Though some blocks show more restoration investment than others, the strong neighborhood association works to maintain affordable options alongside preservation. The area's artistic community contributes to distinctive character through public art installations, gallery spaces, and creative adaptations of historic buildings that honor architectural heritage while accommodating contemporary living.

Hispanic heritage permeates Avenida Guadalupe, where colorful murals and historic buildings showcase San Antonio's Mexican-American culture west of downtown. Residents enjoy authentic family-owned taquerias and bakeries along Guadalupe Street and quick access to the historic Market Square. Though economic challenges affect some areas, community organizations actively work to balance preservation with economic development. The neighborhood's proximity to both downtown attractions and the expanding UTSA Downtown Campus creates improving investment outlook, while strong cultural traditions from Día de los Muertos celebrations to conjunto music venues maintain authentic character regardless of development cycles.

Family-focused convenience characterizes Sierra Springs, where newer homes offer modern amenities and open floor plans northwest of downtown San Antonio. Residents enjoy planned community features including walking trails connecting green spaces and quick access to major shopping along the commercial corridor. Though architectural uniqueness is limited compared to historic areas, the trade-off comes in energy efficiency, technological readiness, and lower maintenance requirements. The neighborhood's thoughtful development includes preservation of mature trees and natural drainage features creating environmental consciousness despite suburban format.

Mid-century character defines Donaldson Terrace, where ranch homes with distinctive architectural details create a cohesive neighborhood near the medical center. Residents enjoy the quiet streets with mature trees and the area's central location with quick access to both downtown and major employers. Though some homes show their age with vintage systems requiring occasional maintenance, the trade-off comes in architectural character and established landscaping unavailable in newer developments. The neighborhood's proximity to medical facilities attracts healthcare professionals seeking reasonable commutes, while the architectural significance appeals to those valuing distinctive design over cookie-cutter modernity.

Historic energy defines Downtown San Antonio, where Spanish colonial architecture alongside modern high-rises creates distinctive character around the famous River Walk. Residents enjoy car-free living with most necessities within walking distance and vibrant street life from mariachi performances to outdoor markets. Though tourism creates seasonal crowding in certain areas, locals quickly learn the quieter sections and off-peak timing for enjoying shared amenities. Many residential buildings feature adaptive reuse of historic structures, creating unique living spaces where modern amenities complement architectural elements connecting to San Antonio's multicultural heritage across centuries of development.

Historic elegance permeates Monte Vista, where Spanish Colonial Revival and Victorian mansions create one of Texas' most architecturally significant neighborhoods. Residents enjoy walkable access to Trinity University and the cafes along Hildebrand Avenue. Though historic designation creates some renovation limitations, the trade-off comes in preserved architectural details and established landscape you simply can't find in newer developments. The neighborhood's century-old oak trees create natural canopies over streets, providing essential shade during San Antonio's hot summers.
knownFor: Family-friendly neighborhood with schools and parks

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Family-friendly Woodstone offers suburban comfort near the Woodstone Elementary School, with wide streets and cul-de-sacs creating safe play areas. Residents enjoy the neighborhood pool during San Antonio's hot summers and walking trails connecting green spaces. Though architectural variety is limited to a few standard models, the well-maintained properties and active community create a welcoming atmosphere for newcomers. Military families appreciate the neighborhood's proximity to Randolph Air Force Base while maintaining distance from flight paths.

Natural beauty surrounds Woodridge, where homes built into hillsides preserve native landscaping and wildlife corridors along Salado Creek. Residents enjoy direct access to the McAllister Park trail system for hiking and mountain biking, while the convenient 281 corridor enables quick downtown commutes. Though summer drought conditions require water-conscious choices, many properties feature xeriscaped gardens showcasing colorful native plants. The neighborhood's elevation provides cooler temperatures than other parts of San Antonio, with evening breezes making outdoor dining possible even during warmer months.
knownFor: Quiet residential neighborhood with schools and parks

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Rural charm persists in Alamo Farmsteads, where properties on larger lots maintain working gardens and fruit trees just minutes from downtown San Antonio. Residents enjoy the neighborhood's mature pecan groves and backyard chicken-keeping traditions, while Woodlawn Lake Park provides waterfront recreation. Though some streets lack sidewalks reflecting the area's former rural status, the trade-off comes in larger yards and established landscaping. The neighborhood's central location offers quick access to the Medical Center and downtown attractions, while several corner markets feature locally-grown produce reflecting the area's agricultural heritage.
knownFor: Family-friendly neighborhood near parks and schools

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Historic charm radiates from 1920s bungalows near San Antonio College. The Prospect Hill Community Garden hosts tamale-making workshops, though summer humidity tests original window AC units. Nightly Union Pacific freight horns remind residents of the active railyard 0.3 miles east.
knownFor: Residential area with proximity to schools

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Military-focused rentals near Joint Base San Antonio feature hurricane-rated windows. 5AM F-35 engine tests rattle dishes - invest in quake-proof shelving.
knownFor: Residential neighborhood with proximity to schools

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Gilded Age mansions converted to luxury rentals circle Mission Reach paddleboard routes. Strict preservation rules prohibit window AC units despite 100°F summers.
knownFor: Historic district with proximity to shopping

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Nestled between Brackenridge Park's Japanese Tea Garden and the San Antonio Zoo, this historic district charms renters with Craftsman bungalows featuring original river rock facades. The weekly Beethoven Hall farmers market provides organic produce, though parking vanishes during Witte Museum's summer night events. Converted carriage houses attract artists seeking studio space.
knownFor: Residential area with historic homes and access to parks and local businesses

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Mid-century modern enthusiasts adore this preserved 1960s enclave featuring atomic ranch homes with original terrazzo floors. The hidden challenge? Original aluminum wiring in 73% of units requires expensive upgrades. Architecture buffs tour the neighborhood's intact Googie-style carports each October.
knownFor: Residential area with proximity to local parks and schools

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Golf enthusiasts gravitate to this enclave surrounding the Burning Tree Country Club's 18-hole course. Community guidelines require weekly lawn maintenance checks, with many complexes offering complimentary landscaping services included in rent. Retirees dominate the Tuesday morning putting green socials.
knownFor: Residential neighborhood with a family-friendly environment and local schools

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Agricultural heritage lingers in this resurgent area where the Braun Road U-Pick Blueberry Farm operates in a century-old barn. Renters love converted farmhouses but note persistent pollen levels during spring harvests. The neighborhood's hidden gem? The monthly "Farm to Fork" supper club in a restored silo.
knownFor: Residential area with proximity to parks

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Military families cluster near Fort Sam Houston, drawn by quick base access through the Walters Street Gate. The catch? 5AM reveille cannon fire echoes across the neighborhood during monthly training exercises. Top perk: The Braun Road Farmers Market's military discount Tuesdays.
knownFor: Residential neighborhood with a mix of single-family homes and apartments

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Family-friendly vibes permeate this master-planned community circling the 200-acre Panther Springs Park. Renters enjoy community pools with lazy rivers but face cookie-cutter architecture - 82% of homes have identical Spanish tile roofs. The hidden hassle? Aggressive grackles dominating parking lots each spring.
knownFor: Residential area with a mix of homes and access to local parks and schools

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Hill Country vistas wow in this master-planned community circling the Canyon Springs Golf Club. Strict HOA rules mandate desert landscaping despite higher water bills - xeriscaping prohibited.

Latino culture pulses here with weekend mariachi brunches at Tommy's Restaurant and the Guadalupe Theater's flamenco shows. Renters enjoy colorful casitas but note limited parking during Fiesta San Antonio parades.
knownFor: Residential area with a mix of single-family homes and apartments

neighborhoodsData.neighborhoodSummary: Family-friendly charm defines this grid of mid-century ranch homes near Comanche Park's splash pad. Renters prize spacious backyards but face limited public transit options. Weekend crowds flock to Eisenhauer Flea Market's 200+ vendor stalls.
knownFor: Residential area with a mix of single-family homes and apartments

content.text:
San Antonio Rent Report: May 2025

Welcome to the Apartment List May 2025 Rent Report for San Antonio, TX. Currently, the overall median rent in the city stands at $1,185, roughly the same as last month. Prices are now down 2.0% year-over-year. Read on to learn more about what’s been happening in the San Antonio rental market and how it compares to trends throughout the broader San Antonio metro area and the nation as a whole.

San Antonio rents are flat month-over-month and down 2.0% year-over-year

The median rent in San Antonio fell by 0.0% over the course of April, and has now decreased by a total of 2.0% over the past 12 months. San Antonio’s rent growth over the past year has is similar to the state average (-2.3%) but has fallen below the national average (-0.3%).

San Antonio rent growth in 2025 pacing similar last year

Four months into the year, rents in San Antonio have risen 0.5%. This is a similar rate of growth compared to what the city was experiencing at this point last year: from January to April 2024 rents had increased 0.3%.

April rent growth in San Antonio ranked #84 among large U.S. cities

San Antonio rents went down 0.0% in the past month, compared to the national rate of 0.5%. Among the nation's 100 largest cities, this ranks #84. Similar monthly rent growth took place in Greensboro, NC (0.0%) and Santa Ana, CA (-0.1%).

San Antonio is the #80 most expensive large city in the U.S., with a median rent of $1,185

Citywide, the median rent currently stands at $1,013 for a 1-bedroom apartment and $1,247 for a 2-bedroom. Across all bedroom sizes (ie, the entire rental market), the median rent is $1,185. That ranks #80 in the nation, among the country's 100 largest cities.

For comparison, the median rent across the nation as a whole is $1,223 for a 1-bedroom, $1,378 for a 2-bedroom, and $1,392 overall. The median rent in San Antonio is 14.9% lower than the national, and is similar to the prices you would find in Louisville, KY ($1,198) and Lexington, KY ($1,159).

San Antonio rents are 2.5% lower than the metro-wide median

If we expand our view to the wider San Antonio metro area, the median rent is $1,216 meaning that the median price in San Antonio proper ($1,185) is 2.5% lower than the price across the metro as a whole. Metro-wide annual rent growth stands at -2.4%, below the rate of rent growth within just the city.

The table below shows the latest rent stats for 5 cities in the San Antonio metro area that are included in our database. Among them, Boerne is currently the most expensive, with a median rent of $1,437. Seguin is the metro’s most affordable city, with a median rent of $907. The metro's fastest annual rent growth is occurring in San Antonio (-2.0%) while the slowest is in Seguin (-17.0%).
You can also use the map below to explore the latest rent trends in the San Antonio metropolitan area.

Methodology

Apartment List is committed to the accuracy and transparency of our rent estimates. We begin with reliable median rent statistics from the Census Bureau, then extrapolate them forward to the current month using a growth rate calculated from our listing data. In doing so, we use a same-unit analysis similar to Case-Shiller’s approach, capturing apartment transactions over time to provide an accurate picture of rent growth in cities across the country. Our approach corrects for the sample bias inherent in other private sources, producing results that are much closer to statistics published by the Census Bureau and HUD. For more details, please see the Apartment List Rent Estimate Methodology.

Data Access

Apartment List publishes monthly rent reports and underlying data for hundreds of cities across the nation, as well as data aggregated for counties, metros, and states. These data are intended to be a source of reliable information that help renters and policymakers make sound decisions. Insights from our data are covered regularly by journalists across the country. To access the data yourself, please visit our Data Downloads Page.

content.title: Overview of Findings
content.body:
Apartment List has released San Antonio’s results from the third annual Apartment List Renter Satisfaction Survey. This survey, which drew on responses from over 45,000 renters, provides insight on what states and cities must do to meet the needs of 111 million American renters nationwide.

"San Antonio renters expressed general satisfaction with the city overall," according to Apartment List. "They gave most categories above average scores."

Key findings in San Antonio include the following:

  • San Antonio renters gave their city a A- overall.
  • The highest-rated categories for San Antonio were affordability, which received an A+),and social life, state and local taxes, quality of local schools, and jobs and career opportunities all received A grades.
  • The areas of concern to San Antonio renters are weather and public transit, which both received B grades.
  • Millennial renters and renters who are parents are equally satisfied with their city, with both giving it an A grade.
  • San Antonio did relatively well compared to other cities in Texas, including Houston (B+), Dallas (B), and Fort Worth (B).
  • San Antonio did relatively well compared to other Southwestern cities, including Las Vegas (C) and Tucson, AZ (D).
  • San Antonio did relatively well compared to other cities nationwide, including Los Angeles, CA (C+), New York, NY (C+) and Miami, FL (C+).

The top rated cities nationwide for renter satisfaction include Scottsdale, AZ, Irvine, CA, Boulder, CO and Ann Arbor, MI. The lowest rated cities include Tallahassee, FL, Stockton, CA, Dayton, OH, Detroit, MI and Newark, NJ.

Renters say:

  • "Huge city that feels like a small town" – Mehgan F.
  • "I hate the traffic, but love the culture and activities" – Arlene H.
  • "Love the San Antonio culture. So much great food and so many fun events like Fiesta in April. There’s always something you can do with the family, especially downtown." – Frank F.
  • "The weather is great and crime isn’t as bad as other cities, but public transit is terrible and it’s nearly impossible to get by without a vehicle" – David S.

For more information on the survey methodology and findings or to speak to one of our researchers, please contact our team at rentonomics@apartmentlist.com.

p13783.randomDetail: Been here about 2 years pretty safe place,it’s a really good location,with restaurants and all shopping centers nearby,plus super clean swimming pool,especially during the summer,really great staff,god bless.

p28539.randomDetail: This was my first apartment I ever lived in alone back when I was 18 and lived there for 3 years; they were nothing but helpful in my transition to adulthood. I had moved back at the beginning of the year and the staff was the same- which speaks volumes for itself!!! Maintenance orders gets done in a timely manner, the property is always clean, it’s a pretty quiet community and there’s definitely a sense of security with it being gated. I work in the apartment industry myself so I have seen my fair share of different communities, this complex is 100% worth it and in a good location, not having to drive too far for essentials along with being right in the middle of everything here in San Antonio. 10/10 for Rosillo Creek, you will love calling this community your home!!! Plus all the natural light you get in your unit as well!!! I love love love it!!!

p79369.randomDetail: My experience with management and living at Villa Rodriguez has been more than what I can ask for. The ladies in the office are excellent and always helping out and also available when needed for help or have questions.

p2193532.randomDetail: Like area and surroundings . Everyone there In office is friendly and very helpful

p26865850.randomDetail: Great people! Great place to live!

p74600038.randomDetail: I feel secure, love the location, management and leasing team
